title: Improve `Run [Build] Tasks` command and dialog

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Issue Type: Feature Request When it comes to executing `Tasks: Run [Build] Tasks`, instead of putting the message, `Fetching [build] tasks...` in the status bar (where I often don't notice it) and waiting for all tasks to be available before showing anything, I would like the dialog to pop up immediately, with that message at the top, and populate as tasks are found. As a rough example (please pardon my [lack of] ms paint skills): ![vscode issue 47449](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/879055/38473412-89788370-3b44-11e8-8d53-2ee1101b409c.png) When I execute `Tasks: Run Build Task` just after opening VSCode, or after VSCode has been inactive for quite a while, the `Fetching build tasks...` job takes a fair bit of time to complete. It completes slightly faster for a single-root workspace than for a multi-root workspace, but it still take an annoyingly long time to complete. I would guess that tasks from `tasks.json` do not take very long to fetch, and the main holdup is waiting for tasks from extensions and from gulp. Since I often want to run a task from `tasks.json`, it would be wonderful to not have to wait for all of the other tasks to populate before I can run one of those. VS Code version: Code 1.22.1 (950b8b0d37a9b7061b6f0d291837ccc4015f5ecd, 2018-04-06T02:26:57.615Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299

title: keybindings using [ContextMenu] key sometimes ALSO trigger UI context menu

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.22.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro 1803 (build: 17133.1)
- Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open keybindings and create a new one (let's call its action `action`). Do not use a "when" clause. Examples:
    - plain: `"key" : "contextmenu"`
    - modifier: `"key" : "alt+contextmenu"`
    - chord + plain: `"key" : "ctrl+shift+alt+space contextmenu"`
    - chord + modifier: `"key" : "ctrl+shift+alt+space alt+contextmenu"`

2. Test the keybinding with various selections and non-selections

Notice that if you use the UI to assign the keybinding, then the "plain" and "chord + plain" examples will trigger the UI context menu (so you will need to press [Esc] and [Enter] to confirm the keybinding) but the "modifier" and "chord + modifier" examples will not.

When the [ContextMenu] key is used unmodified (as in the "plain" and "chord + plain" examples above), then:
- when editor text has focus: *does not* trigger `action` + triggers UI context menu
- outside editor: triggers `action` + triggers UI context menu

When the [ContextMenu] key is used modified (as in the "modifier" and "chord + modifier" examples above), then:
- when editor text has focus: *does not* trigger `action` + triggers UI context menu
- outside editor, with selection: triggers `action` + triggers UI context menu
- outside editor, without selection: triggers `action` + *does not* trigger UI context menu

title: Task: Typescript errors disappear after document closed

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.22.1 (newest) (typescript 2.8.1)
- OS Version: Windows 10 64bit

I expect typescript errors from all files to show until they have been fixed.

Instead, they disappear as soon as the document is closed again (e.g. by randomly clicking on the error list, which causes documents to open & close again)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use this tasks.json (check if the project path fits you first)

```
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "command": "tsc",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": [
        "-w",
        "-p",
        "."
    ],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "isBackground": true,
    "problemMatcher": {
        "base": "$tsc-watch",
        // "owner": "typescript",
        //  "applyTo": "allDocuments"
    }
}
```
2. Start the task
3. Errors will show in error list (hopefully, if there are errors at all)
4. Randomly click between errors of different files in error list. The files will open and close automatically (if they are not pinned). When a file closes, it's errors disappear!

What I have tried:
- $tsc-watch matcher without any other options
- owner property "typescript" or something artificial
- applyTo property all possibilities
- in settings: typescript.validate.enable === false

The "best" in my trial and error endevour I have got was that the errors just persisted, even when fixed, lol :)

My user settings (don't have workspace settings)

```
{
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe",
    "editor.wordWrap": "on",
    "explorer.confirmDelete": false,
    "editor.quickSuggestions": {
        "other": false,
        "comments": false,
        "strings": false
    },
    "editor.autoClosingBrackets": false,
    "explorer.confirmDragAndDrop": false,
    "editor.acceptSuggestionOnCommitCharacter": false,
    "window.zoomLevel": 0,
    "explorer.autoReveal": true,
    "editor.suggestOnTriggerCharacters": true,
    "editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": "on",
    "editor.parameterHints": true,
    "typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled": false,
    // "typescript.validate.enable": false
}
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Instead it currently just acts like the existing column selection isn't there, starts again and results in 2 columns being selected. Example: Start State: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1791243/38450557-4112d52c-3a63-11e8-8bc4-f499761947cf.png) Current State after move caret right and a cursorColumnSelectDown: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1791243/38450573-a8bf8260-3a63-11e8-84de-9d52b19598b6.png) Proposed state after move caret right and a cursorColumnSelectDown: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1791243/38450576-bdfd6426-3a63-11e8-8b0b-5c2da6257838.png) VS Code version: Code 1.22.1 (950b8b0d37a9b7061b6f0d291837ccc4015f5ecd, 2018-04-06T02:26:57.615Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299

title: Make the indents non-editable
body:
Hi, a feature request for the editor:

Proposal is to make the indents non-editable.
(add such edit mode)

How it works: 
- indent char is specified globally in a setup (i.e. \t or space*n)
- those become non-editable, i.e you cannot input anything before 
or inside an indent.
- pressing TAB/SHIFT-TAB indents selected lines more/less

How selection works:
- dragging the mouse highlights text starting 
from the least indented line in the selection
- copy-pasting the selection copies it as if the selected block 
was on zero-indent, thus no need to reformat after pasting -
it will just add indent from the target line (where caret is at pasting)

For pasting from the buffer with unknown preceding whitespace -
add some optional pasting, i.e. char sequences that are parsed as indents.

Ideally, this should affect the **memory representation** also - 
i.e. retrieving the text of line X should give string **without** indent characters,
and give access to additional indent value. 
Why? because IMO this makes much more sense for scripting.

Hope this is clear.
Such feature will significantly reduce finger movements 
and will make editing and scripting more robust.
Further, the non-editable indent space area on the screen can be utilized for 
some mouse click actions - e.g. line selection.

**Demos**

**Caret movements** - walks only in text, remembers position in text:

![caret](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12515548/38472866-16b2a820-3b8f-11e8-921b-32fe5011695b.gif)

**Selection**: do NOT select the indents,  but grabs them only locally - i.e. starting 
from the _least indented line in current selection_ 
(blue bullets - the indents that will be selected and copied):

![selection](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12515548/38472894-7806a9fa-3b8f-11e8-98f5-b949a5a40dc8.gif)

**Copy-pasting**: when pasting, adds the current line's indent to each of the buffer's line, 
which results in precisely formatted lines:

![copy-paste](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12515548/38472937-0c935370-3b90-11e8-8135-1855e84471fb.gif)

title: [html][css] Investigate cross css/html support

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Approach:
- merge HTML & CSS servers to avoid cross LSP communication
- in the server build an (in-memory) index of for the contents of css and html files in the current folder  

Benefits:
In HTML
- code completion in 'class' attributes using the collected class names (same for ids)
- goto & peek references on 'class' attributes (same for ids)

In CSS/LESS/SCSS
- code completion for class names based on already used class names in HTML and CSS (same for ids)
- goto & peek references on 'class' attributes (same for ids)
- code completion for variables defined in other css files

title: Document guidelines to enable language features for embedded languages

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
In VSCode each file is associated with a language. Language supports such as code completion, hovers, are contributed to that language. This is ideally through a language server.
When a language allows to embedded snippets of an other language (e.g. CSS in HTML or HTML in PHP) there are various techniques that a language server can use:

- The language server also implements support for the embedded language. It can do that by including libraries that provide that support. For example there are easy to use node modules for [css, less, scss](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-css-languageservice), [html](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-html-languageservice) and [json](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-json-languageservice) or more basic language supports for [typescript](https://github.com/Microsoft/typescript)
- Forward requests to an other language server as done in [intelephense](https://github.com/bmewburn/vscode-intelephense)

The first approach has the following advantages
- Full control of the user experience. Completion proposals, hovers... can be tuned to apply to the situation.
- No dependencies on other language servers, self contained server that is easy to embedded also in other editors or IDE.

In either case the embedded content needs to be escaped according to the owner language. E.g `>` needs to be `&gt`.

title: Make telemetry Data opt-in
body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.22.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start VS Code 1.22.1 for the first time
2. Now a notification pops up that tells me, that telemetry data is collected and I can opt-out

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

1. I am not sure about this but I don't think collecting telemtry data by default will conform to the General Data Protection Regulation of the EU that becomes effective in May 2018. It would be better to disable it per default and tell the user to enable it if he want's to share data with you.

2. When I checked the privacy policy linked in the notification popup (https://privacy.microsoft.com/en-us/privacystatement) I can't find anything about the data collected by vs code. This is a very important information. This can be a big showstopper for using vscode in some companies, wen data is sent and nobody knows what data this is.

title: tasks.json loading .bashrc *after* executing task
[json] completion has bad replacement span, overwrites comment

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Issue Type: Bug * Open a `tsconfig.json` containing: ```json { "compilerOptions": { "target": "es5" } } ``` * Comment out `//"es5"` * Put a `"` in front of it. Choose the completion that pops up for "es2015". * Result: ```json { "compilerOptions": { "target": "es2015",es5" } } ``` VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.22.0-insider (6b4d53cdab8bcae1eaaa4934d93c077319b573db, 2018-04-04T13:52:38.747Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
System Info |Item|Value| |---|---| |CPUs|Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-1620 v3 @ 3.50GHz (8 x 3492)| |Memory (System)|15.91GB (6.76GB free)| |Process Argv|C:\Program Files\Microsoft VS Code Insiders\Code - Insiders.exe| |Screen Reader|no| |VM|0%|
Extensions: none

title: cwd when running tests is inconsistent across platforms
body:
On Windows, when running tests, `process.cwd()` is the location of VS Code, whereas on macOS it's the extension root folder.

This means relative paths in tests are resolved different; for example the sample code at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node/tree/master/testSupport is relative and fails on Windows (and to make things worse, debugging DebugClient is really frustrating, as it doesn't seem to expose errors or the data going over the protocol easily, and for some reason breakpoints don't seem to work unless they were added in the very same debug session!).

I know things shouldn't really rely on `cwd`, but it's somewhat convenient in tests to not have to join everything so it'd be good if these behaved the same.

title: Add Java to "Tools and Languages" section of the welcome page
body:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16755094/38286245-f2cd9578-37f6-11e8-91ee-a57d77360f13.png)

Can we also add Java among other entries to improve awareness?

We have relatively complete Java support in VS Code with an extension portfolio that covers lots of things:
- [Java Language Support](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=redhat.java)
- [Java Debugger](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vscjava.vscode-java-debug)
- [Java Test Runner - JUnit](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vscjava.vscode-java-test#overview)
- [Maven for Java](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vscjava.vscode-java-test#overview)
- [Spring Boot Extension Pack](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Pivotal.vscode-boot-dev-pack)
- [Tomcat for Java](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vscjava.vscode-java-test#overview)

Java also deserves its place in that list.

title: Make search tree context menu multiselect-aware

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
We need the controller at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/electron-browser/views/explorerViewer.ts#L369 to be not Explorer-specific so it can drive multiselect in other trees.

TreeResourceNavigator https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/platform/list/browser/listService.ts#L456 kind of conflicts with it, need to figure out how that's supposed to work.

We will need a generic version of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/files.ts#L27 currently the keyboard shortcuts on some of the search context menu items don't work for the same reason

title: Add support for "Go to Super/Base" (similar to Go to Implementation)
body:
IntelliJ supports both "Go to Super Method" and "Go to Implementation":

https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/navigating-to-super-method-or-implementation.html

As far as I can tell, Code currently only has the latter so the former has to just be a custom command (which means it may be implemented inconsistently, have inconsistent keybindings, etc.). It'd be better if we could register a SuperProvider (!) to provide this.

(It's possible this has been asked for, but trying to search the issues for `super` returns hundreds of results because people like to use that word!)

title: Allow starting debugging using "current" config with additional arguments

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I'd like to add a command for "Run in Profile Mode" however it should respect the users current debug settings in `launch.json` (and which debug config the have selected in the debug tab), similar to pressing F5.

While the user can add `mode: profile` to the launch.json, it means they'd have to maintain the launch config duplicated and wouldn't be able to key-bind this setting.

Could we have (if there isn't already) a way to start a debug session similar to the user hitting `F5` (currently the startDebug API requires a name/config and doesn't seem to support just using the same thing that F5 would) but that allows some arbitrary config to be passed in (eg. `mode: profile`)?
